natural problem: What is the remainder when $x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x-3$?
natural solution: Using the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $f(x) = x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x - 3$ is $$\begin{aligned} f(3)&=3^4-7\cdot3^3+9\cdot3^2+16\cdot3-13 \\&= 3^3(3-7+3) + 35\\ &= \boxed{8}. \end{aligned}$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "\<exists> R. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = 8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x-3$? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 Using the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $f(x) = x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x - 3$ is $$\begin{aligned} f(3)&=3^4-7\cdot3^3+9\cdot3^2+16\cdot3-13 \\&= 3^3(3-7+3) + 35\\ &= \boxed{8}. \end{aligned}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "\<exists> R. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = x^4 - 7x^3 + 9x^2 + 16x - 13$ and $Q(x) = x - 3$, there exists a function $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = Q(x) \cdot R(x) + 8$ for all $x$. Prove that the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $Q(x)$ is always 8.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "\<exists> R. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = 8"

(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x-3$? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 Using the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $f(x) = x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x - 3$ is $$\begin{aligned} f(3)&=3^4-7\cdot3^3+9\cdot3^2+16\cdot3-13 \\&= 3^3(3-7+3) + 35\\ &= \boxed{8}. \end{aligned}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "\<exists> R. \<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = 8"
 proof-

a_1.informal problem: For all real numbers $x$, let $P(x) = x^4 - 7x^3 + 9x^2 + 16x - 13$ and $Q(x) = x - 3$. There exists a function $R(x)$ such that for all $x$, $P(x) = Q(x) * R(x) + 8$. Show that for all $x$, $P(x)$ modulo $Q(x)$ is equal to $8$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "R x = 8"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x-3$? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 Using the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $f(x) = x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x - 3$ is $$\begin{aligned} f(3)&=3^4-7\cdot3^3+9\cdot3^2+16\cdot3-13 \\&= 3^3(3-7+3) + 35\\ &= \boxed{8}. \end{aligned}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "R x = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that the function $P(x) = x^4 - 7x^3 + 9x^2 + 16x - 13$, $Q(x) = x - 3$, and that $P(x)$ divides $Q(x)$, find a function $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = Q(x) \cdot R(x) + 8$. The final answer is $R(x) = 8$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "R x = x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 5 * x - 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x-3$? The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 Using the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $f(x) = x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x - 3$ is $$\begin{aligned} f(3)&=3^4-7\cdot3^3+9\cdot3^2+16\cdot3-13 \\&= 3^3(3-7+3) + 35\\ &= \boxed{8}. \end{aligned}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "R x = x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 5 * x - 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider a function P(x) = $x^4 - 7x^3 + 9x^2 + 16x - 13$ and another function Q(x) = $x - 3$. If P(x) divides Q(x) and for all x, P(x) equals Q(x) multiplied by another function R(x) plus 8, find the form of R(x). The final answer is $x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x - 3$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "P 3 = 8"

shows  "P 3 = 8"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "\<forall> x. R x = (x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 3 * x + 5)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x-3$? The final Answer is 8

 Using the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $f(x) = x^4-7x^3+9x^2+16x-13$ is divided by $x - 3$ is $$\begin{aligned} f(3)&=3^4-7\cdot3^3+9\cdot3^2+16\cdot3-13 \\&= 3^3(3-7+3) + 35\\ &= \boxed{8}. \end{aligned}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 3 + 9 * x powr 2 + 16 * x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 8"
shows  "\<forall> x. R x = (x powr 3 - 4 * x powr 2 + 3 * x + 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = x^4 - 7x^3 + 9x^2 + 16x - 13$ and $Q(x) = x - 3$, find a function $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = Q(x) \cdot R(x) + 8$ for all real numbers $x$. The final answer is $R(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 + 3x + 5$.
